prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will use a correlator setup that will allow us to get possible serendipitous detections of compact molecular gas emission at a velocity resolution of <1 km/s (after Hanning smoothing). If compact gas emission is present, from previous single dish observations measurements we would expect a brightness temperature around 30 K, which would be detected at a signal-to-noise ratio higher than 6 in the requested time. The line width expected ranges between 6 km/s for high density gas tracers and >10 km/s for molecular outflows. But we point out this is a completely secondary goal for this proposal.
We will observe in 4 spectral windows (one per baseband) in dual polarization mode, with a bandwidth of 1875 MHz per spectral window and ~1 km/s resolution. We will tune the spectral windows to observe CO(3-2) at 345.796 GHz, CS(7-6) at 342.883 GHz, HCO+(4-3) at 356.734 GHz, and HCN(4-3) at 354.504 GHz. This configuration will allow us to get possible serendipitous detections of compact molecular gas emission at a velocity resolution <1 km/s (<2km/s for the case of the HCN spectral window) after Hanning smoothing, without decreasing significantly the continuum sensitivity. Then we will add all channels in all spectral windows for deriving the continuum emission.

The primary goal of this proposal is to detect compact cold dust emission surrounding multiple protostellar systems. We request band 7 because it provides a high signal-to-noise ratio for the dust emission of our candidates in a short integration time and the needed spatial resolution for performing our science case. We expect very compact emission (point-like sources). We aim to detect sources separated <60-100 AU (0.15" at the typical distances of our sources of 400-700 pc), for which we need a resolution of 0.15" or better.

Our aim is to have a detection limit of dust emission below 1 Mjup at a signal-to-noise ratio better than 6. Considering the typical distance of our sources (400-700 pc), and a typical Tdust=20 K and a dust opacity law with exponent beta=1.5 , we would need an rms of 0.1 mJy to achieve our goals. The primary goal of this proposal is to detect compact cold dust emission surrounding multiple protostellar systems. We request band 7 because it provides a high signal-to-noise ratio for the dust emission of our candidates in a short integration time and the needed spatial resolution for performing our science case. We expect very compact emission (point-like sources)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Observations of populations of T Tauri stars have demonstrated that stellar multiplicity is established very early in stellar evolution and it is likely to be linked to the star formation process itself. High-resolution imaging surveys have recently discovered the existence of brown dwarfs to planetary mass companions at large distances from their parent star (>100AU) in nearby star-forming regions, increasing the general interest for understanding the formation of multiple systems. Nevertheless, multiplicity at the early phases of the star formation is still poorly characterized due to the poor sensitivity and spatial resolution of old telescopes to detect dust and molecular gas surrounding the companions. In order to determine the initial conditions of the formation of multiple systems and to identify the dominant physical scales that govern those mechanisms we propose to observe a sample of southern Bok globules to study multiplicity to the limit of planetary-mass (<1Mjup) at the earliest stages in an ideal isolated and simple environment.This will help us to test if core prompt fragmentation is the leading candidate scenario to form multiple systems.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Chile, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
